speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: Sam, have you ever heard the expression ‘a problem shared is a problem halved’?

speaker: Sam
text: Yes, Neil, I have. Doesn’t it mean that people often feel better after talking about their problems with someone?

speaker: Neil
text: Right - in this programme we’ll be hearing the extraordinary story of how these ideas were taken up by a team of community grandmothers in Zimbabwe.

speaker: Sam
text: Zimbabwe has over 14 million people but fewer than 20 psychiatrists. After years of economic turmoil, unemployment and HIV, mental health is a huge challenge, and doctors estimate that one in four Zimbabweans suffers from depression or anxiety.

speaker: Neil
text: When it proved impossible to find free space to use in hospitals, psychiatrist Dr Dixon Chibanda, came up with the idea of turning public park benches into spaces for therapy.

speaker: Sam
text: He recruited grandmothers, who have both free time and plenty of life experience, to talk with individuals struggling with mental health issues like depression, anxiety, and trauma.

speaker: Neil
text: The grandmothers are drawn from the local community and trained over several weeks in a talking therapy called CBT – but what does that abbreviation, CBT, stand for? That’s my quiz question. Is it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) Chatting Based Therapy?,

speaker: Neil
text: b) Conversation Brain Therapy?  or,

speaker: Neil
text: c) Cognitive Behavioural Therapy?

speaker: Sam
text: Well, I think I’ll say c) Cognitive Behavioural Therapy.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out later. Now, although the recent history of Zimbabwe has left millions struggling with mental health issues, at the start of his project, Dr Dixon Chibanda was the only psychiatrist working in public health in the whole country.

speaker: Sam
text: And as well as a lack of provision, many villagers were suspicious of talking therapy, preferring to rely on traditional faith healers instead.

speaker: Neil
text: Which is why when Kim Chakanetsa, of BBC World Service’s The Documentary Podcast, spoke to Dr Dixon Chibanda, she started by asking him whether people were supportive of his idea:

speaker: scepticismresistance
text: Initially there was a lot of scepticism, a lot of resistance, particularly from colleagues who thought this was not evidence-based, and it wasn’t going to work. The whole idea of training grandmothers – I mean, this has not been done anywhere else in the world so naturally there was resistance.

speaker: apprehensive
text: Were you at all apprehensive?

speaker: Dr Dixon Chibanda
text: I was, to be quite honest.

speaker: scepticism
text: At first, Dr Dixon Chibanda’s ideas were met with scepticism – an attitude of doubting whether something is useful or true.

speaker: resistance
text: ‘Grandma benches’ were a totally new idea, never seen before anywhere in the world and so his colleagues naturally felt some resistance - refusal to accept a change or new idea.

speaker: apprehensive
text: Which left Dr Dixon Chibanda feeling a little apprehensive – worried that something bad was going to happen to his project.

speaker: apprehensions
text: Fortunately, as it turned out, Dr Dixon Chibanda’s apprehensions were wrong. Grandmothers are highly respected in Zimbabwean society and as they started listening, people began opening up and telling their stories.

speaker: Sam
text: The ‘grandma benches’ have empowered over 50,000 people to deal with their life problems and Dr Dixon Chibanda even has plans to move his idea online, giving the world access to a virtual Friendship Bench.

speaker: Neil
text: Here he is again, explaining on the BBC World Service’s The Documentary Podcast why he believes his ideas have been so successful:

speaker: custodiansdoes away withstigma
text: It works because it’s simple, it’s cheap and it’s run by communities, particularly grandmothers who are in essence a resource in African communities – you know, they are the custodians of local culture and wisdom – that’s why is works, and I guess, it does away with western concepts which remove the stigma that is normally associated with mental illness.

speaker: custodians
text: Clients are willing to share their problems with the grandmother-therapists because they are respected as cultural custodians – people with responsibility for taking care of something or trying to protect ideas or principles, in this case local customs and wisdom.

speaker: do away withstigma
text: This helps do away with – or remove – the stigma attached to mental health – strong feelings of shame or disapproval which most members of a community have towards something, such as psychological illness.

speaker: Sam
text: For Zimbabweans suffering domestic violence, unemployment and dealing with HIV, having a grandmother to talk to really can change their perceptions about how problems can be managed.

speaker: Neil
text: So it seems true that ‘a problem shared is a problem halved’, which reminds me of our quiz question, Sam.

speaker: Sam
text: Yes. You asked me what the talking therapy abbreviated to CBT stands for. And I said c) Cognitive Behavioural Therapy.

speaker: Neil
text: Which is absolutely right! CBT – a way of managing problems by changing ways of thinking and behaving.

speaker: scepticismresistance
text: So this week we’ve been hearing the inspiring story of Zimbabwean Dr Dixon Chibanda’s ‘grandma bench’ therapy -  an idea which was initially met with scepticism – a doubtful attitude, and resistance – refusal to change and accept new ideas.

speaker: apprehensioncustodians
text: Dr Dixon Chibanda’s feelings of apprehension – worries that the project would fail, proved false when his team of grandmother therapists were treated as custodians – or protectors, of wisdom and life experience who really could help people suffering depression, poverty and trauma.

speaker: do away withstigma.
text: The success of the project helped do away with – or remove – strong feelings of shame or disapproval felt by many people regarding mental health, known as stigma. To hear more inspiring, topical stories, join us again soon here at 6 Minute English. Bye for now!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!
